title: Financial Management
requirements:
1. Pre-requisites: ACCT1111 or ACCT2111 and DOTE1030 or 1031, or permission from instructor
2. Not for students who have taken ECON3540, FINA2110 or FINA2310
description: This course identifies and provides a framework for analysing the major financial decisions by a firm. Issues addressed include valuation, investment decision-making, analysis of risk, financial planning, dividend policy, working capital management, and the financing mix for the firm.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to financial concepts and fundamental principles for undergraduate business students who have little prior knowledge or training in finance. It is intended to be basic. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to: ~ improve their understanding of the vocabulary of finance; ~ communicate more effectively with financial practitioners; ~ develop guidelines to assess the performance of a firm in financial terms; ~ enhance their ability to use financial analysis when required to make decisions; ~ better understand the impact of financial decisions on the performance of a firm; ~ develop a critical thinking mindset.
syllabus: ~ Introduction, Basic Concepts and Principles ~ Time Value of Money: Concepts and Applications ~ Bond and Stock Valuation ~ Making Investment Decisions: Capital Budgeting ~ Leverage and Risks; Making Financing Decisions ~ Capital Structure Decisions ~ Dividend Policy ~ Working Capital Management ~ Evaluating Financial Performance ~ Introduction to Diversification and Asset Pricing
required_readings: ~ Corporate Finance Fundamentals, Ross, Westerfield & Jordan, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill-Irwin, 2010 ~ Fundamentals of Corporate Finance, Ross, Westerfield & Jordan, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill International Edition ~ Corporate Finance, J. Berk and P. DeMarzo, 2nd Edition, Pearson Global Edition

title: Introduction to Empirical Methods in Finance
requirements:
1. Pre-requisites: DOTE2011 or FINA2220
2. Not for students who have taken ECON2121
description: This course introduces to students selected topics in applied statistics which are useful to financial data analysis and research. It provides students with the concepts of regression techniques widely applied in finance, and their hand-on applications and interpretations. Topics include linear regression models, selected introductory topics in regression analysis and time series analysis.

title: Introduction to Actuarial Science
description: This is the first course in actuarial science. The goal of this course is to provide an in depth discussion of financial mathematics for actuarial use and an introduction to risk management.Advisory: elementary calculus as pre-requisite
outcome: After completing this course, students would be familiar with: Present and accumulated values for level as well as varying streams of cash flows (including m-thly and continuous payments), actuarial notations, loan and bond amortization, interest risk management using immunization and interest rate swaps, introduction to derivatives.   在完成本科後， 學生將會熟悉： 現值和期值 (包括等額和非等額年計、一年 m 次和連續現金流 )、精算符號、分期貸款和債券攤銷、利用免疫策略和利率掉期進行利率風險管理、衍生工具簡介。
syllabus: Topics include: (1) Different interest rate conventions, including effective rate, discount rate, discount factor, force of interest, rates convertible  m-thly, real and nominal rate  (2) Actuarial notations and calculation for the following cash flows for yearly, m-thly and continuous payment frequencies:   annuity certain, annuity due and perpetuity, including both level, arithmetically varying, and geometrically varying payments  (3) Loan amortization and sinking fund  (4)  Bond amortization schedule  (5) Term structure of interest rate, forward rates, duration and convexity  (6) Interest rate risk management technique including Redington immunization and cash flow matching (7) Introduction to derivative securities such as a interest rate swaps and related risk management concepts  內容包括： (1) 不同種類的利率, 包括有效利率、折扣率、貼現率、利息強度、一年 m 次年利率、實利率與名義利率 (2) 下列現金流 ( 年計、一年 m 次和連續 ) 的精算符號與運算：即期年金、即付年金、永續年金, 包括等額現金流、等差級數和等比級數現金流 (3) 分期貸款和償債基金  (4) 債券攤銷 (5) 利率期限結構、遠期利率、存續期和凸性 (6) 利率風險管理，包括 Redington 免疫策略和现金流匹配  (7) 衍生工具如利率掉期和相關風險管理既念簡介
required_readings: - Chan and Tse, 2013. Financial Mathematics for Actuaries, Updated Edition, McGraw-Hill Education (Asia) - McDonald, 2012. Derivatives Markets, 3rd Ed., Pearson.
recommended_readings: - Kellison, 2009. The Theory of Interest, 3rd Ed., Irwin / McGraw-Hill. - Hull, 2014. Option, Futures and Other Derivatives, 9th Ed., Prentice Hall.

title: Interest Theory and Finance
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA2200.
description: This course discusses the mathematical and technical aspects of the theory of interest in both discrete and continuous time. Topics include: measurement of interest and discount rates, accumulated value and present value, annuities, sinking funds, amortization of debt, determination of yield rates on securities. Applications include: bond evaluation, mortgages,depreciation methods and life insurance. This course provides the foundation for the study of actuarial mathematics.
outcome: The goal of this course is to provide an understanding of the fundamental concepts of ﬁnancial mathematics, and how those concepts are applied in calculating present and accumulated values for various streams of cash ﬂows as a basis for future use in: reserving, valuation, pricing, duration calculation, asset/liability management, investment income, capital budgeting and valuing contingent cash ﬂows. 金流計算現值及累積值的計算，學習在計算準備金，定價，期限，資產／負債管理，投資收入，資本預算及或有現金流的價值計算時的各樣基本金融知識。
syllabus: Interest Accumulation and Time Value of Money, Annuities, Spot Rates, Forward Rates and the Term Structure, Rates of Return, Loans and Costs of Borrowing, Bonds and Bond Pricing, Bond Yields and the Term Structure, Bond Management, Stochastic Interest Rates 利息累積及金錢的時間值，年金，即期利率及遠期利率，利率的期限結構，回報率，借貸及借貸成本，債券及債券定價，債券收益率及期限結構，債券管理，隨機利率
required_readings: Financial Mathematics for Actuaries, Chan, W.S., Tse, Y.K., McGraw Hill 2011.
recommended_readings: The Theory of Interest, Kellison, S.G., Irwin McGraw Hill 1991.

title: Quantitative Methods for Actuarial Analysis I
description: The purpose of this course is to develop knowledge of the fundamental mathematical tools for quantitatively assessing risk. The application of these tools to problems encountered inactuarial analysis is emphasized. Topics include derivatives and integrals of multivariate functions, simple differential equations, general probability, Bayes' Theorem, univariate and multivariate probability distributions.
outcome: The purposes of this course are  (1) to introduce tools in probability theory for quantitatively assessing risk, and  (2) to build a solid background in mathematics for uses in later courses.  After following FINA2220, students are expected to be • familiar with the basic mathematical tools that are useful in actuarial science • able to use probability to analyze risk  able to handle calculations involving univariate and multivariate probability distributions 本科旨在： (1) 介紹概率論作為數理分析風險之工具；  (2) 為其他科目建立一穩固的數學基礎。 完成FINA2220的學生將熟習： • 運用於精算學上的基本數學工具 • 運用概率分析風險  • 一元與多元概率分佈之運算方法
syllabus: (1) General probability:  Set notation, independent and mutually exclusive events, addition and multiplication law, combinatorics, conditional probability and Bayes’ theorem (2) Univariate probability distributions:  The binomial, negative binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson, uniform, exponential, chi-square, beta, Pareto, lognormal, gamma, Weibull, and normal distribution. Probability mass function / density function, distribution function, quantiles and percentiles, mean and variance, mode and median, moment generating function, transformation (3) Multivariate probability distributions: Joint pmf/pdf, joint distribution, the bivariate normal distribution, joint MGF, conditional and marginal distribution, cova riance and correlation, order statistics, the central limit theorem (1) 概率論：  集合的記法，獨立與互斥事件，概率之加法和乘法定律，組合，條件概率與貝葉氏定理。 (2) 一元概率分佈：  二項、負二項、幾何、超幾何、泊松、均勻、指數、卡方、貝他、柏拉圖、對數正態、伽瑪、韋伯與正態分佈。概率質量/密度函數，分佈函數，四分位數與百分位數，期望值，方差，眾數與中位數。矩母函數，概率分佈之變換。 (3) 多元概率分佈： 聯合概率質量/密度函數與分佈，二元正態分佈，聯合矩母函數，條件與邊際分佈，協方差與相關係數，次序統計量，中央極限定理。
required_readings: Sheldon M. Ross (2009). A First Course in Probability. 8th Ed., Prentice Hall.
recommended_readings: Elementary level: • S. Ghahramani (2005). Fundamentals of Probability. 3rd Ed., Prentice Hall. • R. V. Hogg and E. A. Tanis (2001). Probability and Statistical Inference. 6th Ed., Prentice Hall. Advanced level: • W. Feller (1968). An Introduction to Probability Theory and its Applications, Volume I. 3rd Ed., John Wiley and Sons. • D. Williams (2001). Weighing the Odds − A Course in Probability and Statistics, Cambridge University Press.

title: Quantitative Methods for Actuarial Analysis II
requirements: Pre-requisites: FINA2220 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is a continuation of FINA2220. It covers theories in mathematical statistics that are useful in actuarial analysis.
outcome: Upon completion of the course students are expected to acquire a strong foundation in estimation and statistical inference. Topics include: Sampling distribution, methods and properties of estimation, confidence intervals, concepts of hypothesis testing including Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio test, Fisher information, model selection.   在完成本科後，學生將會得到估量法與假設檢定之堅實基礎。本科將檢討： 抽樣分佈、不同估量法之特性、置信區間、假設檢定之理論，包括 NP 引理、似然比測試、費希爾資訊、模型選擇。
syllabus: The general scope of the course content includes:  (1) Sampling distribution including the chi-square, t and F distribution (2) Point estimation: including method of moments, maximum likelihood estimation, and the application of criteria such as  consistency, unbiasedness and minimum variance (3) Tests of statistical hypotheses, including power functions, Type I  and Type II errors, Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood test  (4) Applications of sampling distributions to confidence intervals and  to tests for means and variances, chi-square test of   goodness of fit (5) Bayesian statistics  內容包括： (1) 抽樣分佈 (卡方, t, F 分佈) (2) 點估量：矩估計、最大似然法、估量標準確 ( 如一至性、無偏差、最小方差 ) (3) 假設檢定，包括效能、第一類與第二類錯誤、NP 引理、似然比測試  (4) 抽樣分佈對於平均與方差之置信區間與假設檢定之應用，卡方適合度檢定 (5) 貝業氏統計
required_readings: Hogg, Tanis, and Zimmerman, 2015. Probability and Statistical Inference, 9th Ed., Pearson.
recommended_readings: - Hogg, McKean and Craig, 2012. Introduction to Mathematical Statistics, 7th Ed., Pearson. - Wackerly, Mendenhall, 2008. Mathematical Statistics with Applications, 7th Ed., Thomas Brooks. - Miller and Miller, 2012. John Freund’s Mathematical Statistics with Applications, 8th Ed., Pearson.

title: Fundamentals of Business Finance
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON3540, FINA2010 or FINA2110.
description: This course introduces non-business students to the foundations for finance. It identifies and provides a framework for analysing major financial decisions of a firm. Issues addressed include valuation, investment decision-making, analysis of risk, financial planning, dividend policy, working capital management and the financing mix for the firm. This course will also provide the economics and accounting background necessary for fundamental financial analysis.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to financial concepts and fundamental principles for undergraduate non-business students who have little prior knowledge or training in finance. syllabus: Time Value of Money: Concepts and Applications, Bond and Stock Valuation, Making Investment Decisions: Capital Budgeting, Leverage and Risks, Capital Structure Decisions, Dividend Policy, Working Capital Management, Evaluating Financial Performance

title: Financial Markets
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON3520.
description: This course deals with a number of financial instruments traded in the markets for securities, foreign exchange, options and futures. Discussions include intersectoral flow-of-funds analysis, determination of interest rates and analysis of money and capital markets.
outcome: This course aims to provide an overview of the role of financial sector and the functions of different financial instruments traded in key financial markets, with particular emphasis to the Hong Kong environment. Interest rate and its impact on financial markets will also be discussed.
syllabus: ~ Introduction ~ Interest Rates ~ Foreign Exchange Market ~ Debt Securities Market ~ Equity Securities Market ~ Derivative Securities Market
required_readings: Mishkin, Frederic S., and Eakins, Stanley. 2018, Financial Markets and Institutions, 9th Global Edition, Pearson
recommended_readings: ~ Financial Markets and Institutions: An Introduction to the Risk Management Approach, Saunders A. & M.M. Cornett, 3rd Edition, International Edition, McGraw-Hill 2007  ~ A Guide to the Equity Markets of Hong Kong, McGuinness P.B., Oxford University Press 1999

title: International Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course aims to analyse international monetary relations and problems. Major areas of discussion include basic concepts and analysis of the balance of payments, the foreign exchange market, determination of spot and forward exchange rates, international capital flows, the payments adjustment mechanism, international monetary problems and arrangements, and international debt and its development.
outcome: To provide students with the theoretical backgrounds necessary to appreciate and understand problems faced by financial managers in an international setting.  (1) To discuss current developments in the international financial arena; (2) To understand the basics of international financial environments; (3) To examine the use of international financial markets to control risk and maximise firm value; and (4) To apply and integrate relevant concepts through written essays.
syllabus: To examine decision-making in International Business Finance via a broad study of the opportunities and problems encountered when financial decisions are made across national boundaries. Emphasis will be placed on how conventional financial models require modifications in a global context, and on the use of international financial markets to control risks and maximize firm value.
required_readings: ~ Multinational Business Finance, Eiteman, Stonehill and Moffett, 12th Edition (Global edition available) 2010 (ESM)
recommended_readings: ~【貨幣、外匯及股市】蘇偉文、梁嘉銳、殷偉憲，明報出版社，2003。 ~【香港資產市場】蘇偉文、梁嘉銳，明報出版社，2004。

title: Management of Financial Institutions
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course discusses the economic and environmental problems in the acquisition and use of funds by financial institutions. The emphasis is on the fundamental principles underlying the organization and management of a commercial bank. Considerations are given to recent developments in banking regulations, electronic banking, asset and liability management, various major policy areas and their interrelationships.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to know the nature of banking and other financial institutions and the role of financial institutions in society and the regulatory environment set up to protect those roles
syllabus: The nature of banking, liquidity management, capital adequacy and interest rate risk, credit risk, probanker, commercial bank, asset management, valuation of bank equity, securitization, the banking crisis, credit default swaps, constellation: distribution of minibonds
required_readings: Brueggeman, William B. and Jeffrey D. Fisher, Real Estate Finance and Investments (15th Edition or other recent editions.), McGraw-Hill
recommended_readings: David C. Ling and Wayne R. Archer, 2009, Real Estate Principles: A Value Approach (3nd ed.), McGraw-Hill.Brown & Matysiak, Real Estate Investment, (2000)Waxman, P. 2004, Investing in Residential Property: Understanding the Australian Property Market (6 Edition), Wrightbooks, Melbourne.

title: Central Banking and Regulation of Financial Institutions
requirements:
1. Prerequisites: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken GLEF4020.
description: This course deals with the structure and operations of commercial and central banks. It examines supply of money, process of deposit creation in commercial banks, the tools and impact of monetary policy and the role of central banking in the banking industry. It also considers banking practices in an international context.

title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: In this course, attention will focus on the following issues: the relationship between economic growth and real estate investment, the appraisal of property investment and leasing, the sources and availability of financing for property investment, the legal and regulatory framework underpinning property contracts and mortgage arrangements in Hong Kong (and mainland China), the inter-relationships between property rentals, real estate values and stock market growth and, finally, recent developments and trends in the field of property financing and investment.

title: Corporate Finance: Theory and Practice
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON3540.
description: This course builds on the concepts introduced in FINA2010 and aims to provide students with advanced study of corporate investment and financing decisions. Major topics covered include working capital management, capital budgeting, capital structure, sources of financing, dividend policy, leasing, and mergers and acquisitions.
outcome: The goal of this course is to develop the concepts of modern financial theory and practical tools essential to corporate financial and investment decisions. Hence, it combines lectures, problem solving, academic paper reading and case analysis. Lectures and problem sets are used to horn the skills, academic paper reading deepens the understanding, and cases develop our decision-making ability under the complex real-world situation.

title: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON3520.
description: This course discusses basic security valuation theories and portfolio management. Emphasis is placed on fundamental common stock analysis, capital market theory, analysis of portfolio performance, market efficiency, and behaviour of stock prices.
outcome: It is intended for students who want to become investment professionals, knowledgeable individual investors, or both.
syllabus: The course covers the primary financial securities: bonds, stocks, and derivatives, and methods for combining these underlying assets into a portfolio.
required_readings: Essentials of Investments, Bodie, Kane, and Marcus, 8th ed., McGraw-Hill
recommended_readings: Investments, Bodie, Kane and Marcus, 7th-9th ed., McGraw-Hill

title: Understanding China's Financial System
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3010 or FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: Over the past decades, China’s financial system has become well-established and developed and plays an increasingly important role in driving the country’s fast economic growth. While there are similarities, China’s financial system is vastly different from those in the West, calling for a close scrutiny. However, most finance courses offered at CUHK and in standard textbooks focus primarily on developed markets, neglecting the uniqueness and complexity of the Chinese market.

title: Issues in Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course introduces current issues and topics in finance. This is a student-oriented course and students are required to research and discuss articles on related topics. This course provides an opportunity for students to integrate knowledge acquired from finance courses under the guidance of an instructor. Group-based research projects will be conducted. Weekly presentations will be held. Requirements include the writing of reports, formal term-end presentations of papers and participation in class discussions.

title: Risk Management and Insurance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life, property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy. In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management.
outcome: After completing the course, the students should be able to: (1) understand the risk and risk management; (2) apply legal principles in the risk management area; (3) comprehend insurance contracts such as corporate property insurance, liability insurance and life and health insurance; (4) know how insurance companies operate under regulations. 學生們在完成本科目後，應該能夠：（1）瞭解風險與風險管理含意；（2）應用風險管理領域的法律原則；（3）解讀壽險與非壽險的保險合約；（4）認識在監管下的保險公司運作。
syllabus: This course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life, property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy. In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management.  Topics below will be covered:  1. Risk and Its Treatment 2. The Insurance Mechanism 3. Fundamentals of Risk Management 4. Legal Principles in Insurance 5. Analysis of Insurance Contracts 6. Liability Risk 7. Fundamentals of Life Insurance 8. Contractual Provisions in Life Insurance 9. Life Insurance Purchase Decisions 10. Selected sections (with local relevance) 11. Types of Insurers and Marketing Systems 12. Insurance Company Operations 13. Financial Operations of Insurers 本科內容包括風險管理之概念；風險之鑒別與衡量；產業、利益、與責任性損失範圍；保險收費之擬定方法與問題；以及政府對保險業所訂之法例與政策等。本科將保險學之探討列為風險管理之主要工具。

title: Life Contingencies I
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): FINA2210 or FINA2200
description: This course develops the student's knowledge of the theoretical basis of actuarial models and the application of those models to insurance for a single life. Applications include: premium rate for life insurance and annuity contracts, and benefit reserves for insurance contracts.

title: Basic Long-term Actuarial Mathematics
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2200 or FINA2210
description: This course develops the student's knowledge of the theoretical basis of actuarial models and the application of those models to long-term insurance for a single life. Applications include: premium rate for life insurance and annuity contracts, and reserves for insurance contracts.
outcome: After completing the course, the students should be able to: gain a deep knowledge in survival distributions and life tables; understand the basic present-value model; apply the present-value model to various life insurance and annuity products; combine basic concepts to determine premiums and reserves for general insurance contracts. 完成科目後，學生應該能夠： 深入了解生存分佈和生命表； 了解基本的現值模型； 將現值模型應用於各種人壽保險和年金產品； 結合基本概念來確定一般保險合同的保費和準備金。
syllabus: 1. Survival Distributions and Life Tables - Parametric survival models and life tables, and the associated actuarial functions; select life tables; mortality improvement models2. Life Insurance - Life insurances with different protection and time of benefit payment provisions; statistical properties of present-value of benefit random variables for different life insurances; portfolio of life insurance 3. title: Cases in Corporate Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3070 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to apply the materials learned in financial management to study cases in corporate finance. The cases include capital budgeting under uncertainty with emphasis on the net present value rule, internal rate of return rule and (discounted) payback rule, replacement of old equipment by new equipment, estimation of cost of equity, cost of debt and weighted average cost of capital, the implications of the capital asset pricing model and the arbitrage pricing model, the dividend discount model, optimal capital structure and the free cash flow model.

title: Mergers and Acquisitions
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3070 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to provide an overview of current issues and recent developments in the area of acquisition/merger policy, performance and analysis. This course will focus on the following areas: 1) forms of takeover mechanism and their historical incidence in Hong Kong, 2) causes and motivations for acquisition/merger, 3) the impact on the stock prices of the corporate raider and its target, 4) the Hong Kong regulations relating to mergers and, finally, 5) a consideration of the general effect of mergers/acquisitions upon national economic performance.
outcome: This course is designed to integrate the materials of financial management and investments to analyze the merger and acquisition (takeover) markets. Students are required to apply the efficient market hypothesis to analyze the stock market responses to takeover announcements; the welfare gains or losses to shareholders will be computed. It is also required to compute the cost of capital and to future compute the intrinsic value of targets by using the price multiples, dividend discount model and the free cash model.
syllabus: ~ Introduction to Mergers and Acquisitions and Corporate Strategy ~ Introduction to ISC and IPD ~ ISC in Marketing and Financial Management ~ ISC in Business Innovation and Entrepreneurship ~ IPD in Business Diversification ~ ISC and IPD in Cross-border Acquisitions ~ Financial Decision - Making Tools
required_readings: Mergers, Acquisitions, and Other Restructuring Activities, by Donald DePamphilis. Elsevier. ISBN: 978-0-12-801609-1

title: China Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of China finance. It covers the following areas: China's markets for securities and foreign exchange, their regulatory framework, price behaviour and efficiency, recent developments and trends; the ownership structure, capital structure, dividend policy, and project financing of state-owned as well as privately-owned corporations. Important current issues will also be discussed.

title: Options and Futures
requirements:
1. Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON4450.
description: This course aims to discuss the basic operations of the options and futures markets. It analyses option pricing models, investment strategies involving options and futures, and the roles of hedgers and investors in these markets. Other major topics include comparisons of options and futures contracts issued by different exchanges and their trading regulations.
outcome: This course is designed to study derivative securities and markets. Three fundamental issues will be addressed: operations of various derivative markets; pricing of derivative assets; and their applications in investments and financial management.  The course is conceptual in orientation due to the nature of the material covered. However, practical applications are emphasised. The key is to understand the basic concepts of the subject matter and to relate them to real-world financial issues. The students are expected to have some knowledge of calculus and statistics.

title: Fixed Income Securities Analysis
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: The focus of this course is on the valuation of fixed-income securities and investment techniques in managing fixed-income portfolios. Topics include the term structures of interest rates and forward rates; bond pricing, interest rate and reinvestment risks; risk and hedging in bond portfolio management; duration, convexity and portfolio immunization; corporate bonds, emerging-market bonds and default risks; fixed-income securities with embedded options; callable and convertible bonds, mortgage-backed securities; interest rate derivatives; and interest rate futures, swaps, caps and floors.
outcome: After taking this course, students are able to understand the basic characteristics of fixed-income securities, their market convention and trading mechanism.

title: Empirical Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to apply mathematical and statistical/econometric techniques to financial issues. Topics include mean-variance portfolio analysis; regression and time series analysis of financial data; forecasting and simulations in financial applications. This course involves extensive usage of computers and relevant software packages.

title: Computational Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: Computational finance is an interdisciplinary subject of probability theory, finance, and numerical analysis. The emphasis of this course is on computational methods and mathematical models for various asset pricing and risk management problems. Computational issues on implementing common financial models will be discussed. Standard as well as exotic derivatives on equities, indices, and interest rate will be introduced; different computational methods are used for their pricing and hedging, these include pricing by formulas and approximations, pricing using lattices, and pricing using Monte Carlo simulation. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in at least one computer language.

title: Quantitative Methods for Financial Derivatives
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course develops the quantitative methods for stochastic models of financial markets and pricing financial derivative securities. Topics will include: arbitrage, interest rate and discounted value; hedging strategies and risk management; geometric random walk and Brownian motion as models of risky assets; initial boundary value problems for the heat and related partial differential equations; self-financing replicating portfolio; Black-Scholes pricing of European options; term structure models and interest rate derivatives; Girsanov theory and equivalent martingale measures; optimal stopping and American options. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in probability theory and differential equations.
outcome: Through extensive use of the securities trading and research laboratory, students are expected to be familiar with trading of financial derivatives in a real world setting.
syllabus: Trading of financial derivatives in general, theory behind liquidity providing and market making, pure arbitrage, option theory in practice, statistical arbitrage/ market making options, hedging strategies and risk management.

title: Intermediate Financial Theory
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course presents and develops many of the important concepts in finance. The major focus is on single-period models of financial markets and the valuation of simple financial claims traded in those markets. Topics will include: models of choice under uncertainty, risk aversion, and stochastic dominance; single-period portfolio optimization problems and equilibrium models of asset markets; mutual fund separation theorems and aggregation theorems; introduction to asset markets and portfolio choice in a multi-period context; financial decisions of firms and the Modigliani-Miller theorems; financial equilibrium with differential information. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in microeconomic theory and advanced calculus.

title: Behavioral Finance
requirements:
1. Pre-requisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON4470
description: Traditional finance seeks to understand financial markets assuming that investors are “rational.” Rationality means that investors can access to and have the ability to process information correctly and that competition between investors ensures that securities are correctly priced to reflect all available information. That is, the market is efficient. However, recent studies suggest that markets are not efficient and that investors are not fully rational. For example, particular trading strategies based on past information such as past returns and accounting information are able to outperform the markets. In addition, studies find that investors are committed to certain heuristic-based biases and frame dependent such as overconfidence, optimism, self-attribution, illusion of control, loss aversion, representativeness heuristic, anchoring, availability, ambiguity aversion, hindsight, flaming, etc. Behavioral biases combined with limits to arbitrage may result in securities not to be correctly priced.This course will help students understand how individuals’ attitudes and behaviors affect their financial decisions and financial markets. In the practical side, this course will emphasize the role of investors’ psychological biases on various types of market inefficiency and show that how sophisticated investors can take advantage of these behavioral biases. This is a research oriented course with emphasis on both psychology theories and data analysis skills.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to:  1) Understand the weakness of utility functions in neo-classical economics in describing behaviors and choices of rational agents; 2) Establish a good foundation in psychology in understanding major behavioral biases and human natures that systematically affect decision making; 3) Understand the origin of market inefficiency and return predictabilities; 4) Carry out trading strategies to take advantage of behavioral biases of irrational investors; 5) Carry out quantitative analyses of individual corporate events that are significantly affected by behavioral biases of investors and managers.

The characteristics of the various corporate entities and the nature of the funding methods utilized are critically explored. Finally, dual listings, such as American depositary receipts, and alternative routes to listing (‘reverse takeovers’) are also assessed. Upon completion of the course, students will have developed key insights into a major global funding activity.

title: M&A: Incentives, Valuation & Impact

description: This course is designed to integrate the materials of financial management and investments to analyse the merger and acquisitions (takeover) markets. The class will be conducted through both lectures and student presentations. Foundations in finance will be covered through lectures format. Students will be grouped and are required to present real cases in Hong Kong. It is not mandatory to work on a real project. However, students have the options to do so. The class is required to apply the efficient markets hypothesis to analyze stock markets' responses to takeover announcements. Welfare gains or losses to shareholders will also be computed. title: Machine Learning in Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Finance
description: This course provides an overview of the basic tools in machine learning, with emphases on applications in finance. Machine learning plays an important role in FinTech. Individual investors and financial institutions who are able to leverage these new tools and technology will have a significant advantage. This course discusses these new opportunities and challenges. It seeks to equip students with these highly coveted skills in the market. We will cover topics including: cluster analysis, decision trees, support vector machines, flexible discriminants, and neural networks, accompanied with the corresponding financial applications. Real world finance problems often deal with large datasets, traditionally with historical price and return as well as data on financial statements. More recently, other databases like consumer credit and online data (e.g., Google search, news media, satellite images, etc.) are also becoming more important for financial analysts. Dealing with such large datasets require tools to manipulate them, and we will introduce the use of Python and detailed instructions on how to perform analysis on large datasets. Once students become comfortable with the use of Python and manipulation of large sets, we will introduce students to tools in machine learning, which play an important role in our financial market, from approving loans, managing portfolios, to assessing risks. Advances in machine learning technology have enabled financial institutions to explore the applications of artificial intelligence in areas like customer service, personal finance, wealth management, and risk management.

title: Venture Capital & Private Equity
requirements: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Finance
description: The course will outline the mechanisms of venture capital (VC) investment and the financing of startups and early growth firms. As VC is a subset of private equity, the course will discuss the management, legal and marketing issues of private equity in general. Topics include raising and structuring private equity funds, the limited partnership, and fund strategies. The course will consider the investment decision of institutional investors in private equity and how funds are structured to meet their needs. It will discuss post-subscription private equity fund management - deal screening, evaluation, negotiation, disbursement, investee management, valuation and exit - and will consider specifically the perspective of the VC investee company - alternative sources of financing, how to approach a VC to maximize chances of success, and governance issues in VC financed firms. The course may also delve into public versus private equity buyouts, valuation of buyouts and corporate restructuring under private equity.
outcome: Students should be able to have a general understanding of private equity investment cycle from pre-investment, investment, post-investment and exit. In addition, the typical private equity fund legal structure are covered and explained such that students shall be able to understand the basic idea of designing a private equity fund which caters for the requirements of investor and the investment manager. Students shall also be able to learn valuation, negotiation and several key considerations on how does a PE/VC investment decision is made, both from the investor and the investee perspectives. As such, students shall be able to have the basic understanding of PE/VC industry and be able to communicate with stakeholders typically involve in PE/VC deals.

title: Behavioral Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Finance
description: Traditional finance seeks to understand financial markets assuming that investors are "rational". Rationality means that investors can access to and have the ability to process information correctly and that competition between investors ensures that securities are correctly priced to reflect all available information. That is, the market is efficient. However, recent studies suggest that markets are not efficient and that investors are not fully rational. For example, particular trading strategies based on past information such as past returns and accounting information are able to outperform the markets. In addition, studies find that investors are committed to certain heuristic-based biases and frame dependent such as overconfidence, optimism, self-attribution, illusion of control, loss aversion, representativeness heuristic, anchoring, availability, ambiguity aversion, hindsight, flaming, etc. Behavioral biases combined with limits to arbitrage may result in securities not to be correctly priced.This course will help students understand how individuals’ attitudes and behaviors affect their financial decisions and financial markets. In the practical side, this course will emphasize the role of investors’ psychological biases on various types of market inefficiency and show that how sophisticated investors can take advantage of these behavioral biases. This is a research oriented course with emphasis on both psychology theories and data analysis skills.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to:  1) Understand the weakness of utility functions in neo-classical economics in describing behaviors and choices of rational agents; 2) Establish a good foundation in psychology in understanding major behavioral biases and human natures that systematically affect decision making; 3) Understand the origin of market inefficiency, financial market bubbles and crashes, and return predictabilities; 4) Carry out trading strategies to take advantage of behavioral biases of irrational investors; 5) Carry out quantitative analyses of individual corporate events that are significantly affected by behavioral biases of investors and managers. 6) Understand the role and economic incentives of financial analysts in financial markets.

It covers issues including bank's payment operations and their roles, the general principles of bank lending, the range of credit services available and the principles of taking securities, trade finance, credit cards and some other major banking services. Various bank risk management methods are conducted in a simulated environment.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students are expected to understand the business models of commercial banking, along with key management techniques and tools.
syllabus: We will compare the organizational and operational structures of banks, with services related to both corporate and retail banking. As a global regulatory trend, capital management is becoming a key requirement and we’ll discuss and quantify the rationale behind it. Management practice and evolution in western banks will be introduced, and we will further extend the discussion to the practices in Chinese banks.

title: Insurance and Risk Management
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: This course deals with risk management functions in business; the identification and measurement of business loss exposures; major tools of risk management; analysis of insurance contracts and their uses; methods and problems of insurance pricing; operations of insurers and major insurances policies; family property and liability risk management; and government regulation of insurance.

title: Merger, Acquisition and Reconstruction of Corporate Finance
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: This course integrates areas within financial management and investments to analyse merger and acquisition (takeover) markets. The class will be conducted using both lectures and presentations. The topics covered in lectures will include the overview of takeover markets, legal aspects and restrictions, capital budgeting techniques, the efficient market hypothesis, the market model and computation of abnormal returns, the dividend discount model and the free cash flow model. The topics covered in presentation will include US and Hong Kong cases of mergers, tender offers and leverage buyouts. The class is required to apply the efficient market hypothesis to analyse the stock market responses to takeover announcements. In addition, consideration will be given to welfare gains/losses associated with takeover, the cost of capital for due acquirer and the intrinsic value of the target (using dividend discount and free cashflow models).
outcome: Students will: - understand how to analyse strategic activities of a company and target a company - be familiar with different ways of merger and acquisition - understand how a targeted company adopt anti-M&A strategies to protect the interests of the company and shareholders - be able to design and carry out M&A activities, including due diligence, valuation, post merger integration, etc. - be familiar with the development history and trend in M&A, various M&A activities, motives and relevant theories
syllabus: We will analyze the company's strategic activities, and determine the target company's M&A method.

title: Entrepreneurship in Finance
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: Entrepreneurship in Finance is a capstone course that gives all students the opportunity to integrate all they have learned before to develop an actual business model. title: Law and the Securities Markets
requirements: For students in MSc Finance
description: This course is designed to introduce students already familiar with the economics of securities markets to the law that governs those markets and the transactions in securities they are designed to execute. The course will closely examine actual legal documentation to show its basic structure and purpose. Further, the course will analyze basic legal principles that shape the law and regulation of corporate finance and securities markets, such as legal strategies to overcome asymmetric information, moral hazard and agency problems, as well as techniques to secure prior claims against assets held in the possession of another entity in any bankruptcy proceedings regarding that entity.
outcome: After the course, students shall: - be able to read legal documents relevant for financial decision making  - have a thorough understanding of the underlying legal principles related to regulation and outside regulation and critically evaluate relevant theories and frameworks - be able to appreciate the importance of legal dimensions in corporate finance - be able to integrate the legal principles with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., economics and accounting) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems - be able to communicate issues involving law and securities market in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts

requirements: For students in EMBA (Chinese); or MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)

requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: In this course we will use psychology and more realistic settings to guide and develop alternative theories of financial markets. We will examine how the insights of behavioral finance complement the traditional paradigm and shed light on investors' trading patterns, the behavior of asset prices, corporate finance, and various Wall Street institutions and practices.
outcome: Students will:  - understand why and how value investment can be an effective investment approach by using the academic paradigm of behavioral finance - be familiar with private equity, asset prices and corporate finance in the context of urban economics  - understand how these markets have been developing in Mainland China compared with the international experiences

title: Quantitative Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Finance
description: This course explores quantitative methods in credit risk management and examines market risks, operational risks, integrated risk management, and risk management information technology. Basic Value-at-Risk (VaR) methodologies such as historical simulation, parametric VaR, delta-gamma approximation and Monte-Carlo simulation will be covered. Defaults of bank loans, corporate bonds, and/or counter-parties are addressed. Reduced-form models and structure models are discussed, with application of CreditmetricsTM and KMV methodologies.
outcome: After the course, students should:  - have a thorough understanding of quantitative risk management and appreciate its importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts - be able to critically evaluate theories, frameworks, and techniques of quantitative risk management  - be able to reason quantitatively using different methodologies  - have the operational skills for assessing and managing credit risks using IT systems - be able to integrate the quantitative risk management principles with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., economics, accounting, and law) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems  - be able to communicate risk management issues in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts
syllabus: Risk & Risk Management  - Introduction - Market risk & operational risk - Integrated risk management  - Risk management information technology  Basic methodologies - Value-at-Risk (VaR)  - Historical simulation - Parametric VaR - Delta-gamma approximation  - Monte-Carlo simulation  Portfolio risk management - Portfolio risk management - Asset allocation  - Measuring the performance of portfolio managers - Defaults of bank loans, corporate bonds and/or counter-parties - Reduced-form models and structure models to credit risk CreditmetricsTM and KMV methodologies   Operational risk management  - Techniques to operational risk management

title: Bank and Insurance Capital
requirements: For students in MSc Finance
description: The course offers a comprehensive understanding of Basel I, II, and III. The standard internal ratings-based (IRB) approach, as well as the foundation internal ratings-based (FIRB), and advanced internal ratings-based (AIRB) approaches, will be covered. The 3 Pillars for banking capital will be explored. Students are guided through practical implementation of different capital requirements under different regulatory frameworks.

title: Mathematical Financial Modeling and Structured Solutions
requirements: For Students in MSc Finance
description: The course introduces mathematical modeling concepts and techniques for financial applications. The classic Black-Scholes Model, local volatility, stochastic volatility are critically evaluated. Interest rate models such as Ho-Lee, Hull-White, Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM), Libor Market Model are discussed. Cross currency models for foreign exchanges and modeling for commodity are also covered.
outcome: After the course, students should:  - have an applied understanding of mathematical finance modeling and appreciate their importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts  - have the mathematical / technical skills for developing mathematical finance models under guidance  - be able to adopt the modeling techniques in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems
syllabus: Mathematical financial modeling - Problems of classic Black-Scholes Model - Local volatility - Stochastic volatility  Interest rate models - Ho-Lee - Hull-White - Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) - Libor Market Model  Other models  - Cross currency models for foreign exchanges  - Modeling for commodity

title: Economics for Actuaries
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course provides an introduction to the basic tools of micro- and macroeconomic analysis, and how these can be used in an insurance business environment to help decision making and behavior. Topics include macroeconomic role of insurance, the demand and supply of insurance, adverse selection, moral hazard, imperfections in insurance markets, utility functions, and the life cycle hypothesis.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to critically appraise key economic concepts, models and theories of microeconomics and macroeconomics; to apply a range of techniques including calculations and manipulation of diagrammatic representations to solve  problems related to economic concepts and models; to evaluate the role of the government and the central bank and the instruments available to them to manage the economy, and to recognize and relate the relevance of economic theory to the wider business environment and describe the link between these theories to the practical application of individual businesses.
syllabus: Micro: Supply and demand; utility theory and risk aversion; production choices; competition; Macro: Fiscal and monetary policy; exchange rates; factors affecting inflation, unemployment, exchange rates and economic growth; introductory game theory; introduction to insurance economics.

title: Accounting and Corporate Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: The course provides both a framework for and the tools necessary to analyse financial statements of an insurance company. Topics include financial ratios, equity and debt capital, weighted-average cost of capital, capital budgeting, and rates of investment return.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of:• the purpose, limitations, layout and presentation of financial statements;• cost analysis in the context of short and long term decision making and the use of discounted cash flow analysis;• financial strategy including capital structure, dividend policy and corporate governance of firms;• the importance of capital structure and dividend policy decisions;• the assumptions underlying the preparation, interpretation and analysis of the Income Statement, Financial position statement and Cash Flow Statement.
syllabus: Concepts and topics listed below should be covered:Accounting• Describe the basic principles of corporate taxation and the taxation of investments held by institutions.• Explain why companies are required to produce annual reports.• Explain fundamental accounting concepts and terms, and describe the main sources of accounting regulation.• Explain the structure and purpose of the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, and the interactions between them.• Construct simple statements of financial position and profit or loss.• Calculate and interpret financial ratios.Corporate Finance•Explain the characteristics of various forms of equity capital from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.• Explain the characteristics of various forms of long-term debt capital from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.• Explain the characteristics of various forms of short- and medium-term financing from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.• Calculate weighted-average cost of capital.• Explain the main methods of capital budgeting.• Calculate a project’s investment return.

title: Probability with Applications in Finance and Insurance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: The purpose of this course is to develop knowledge of the fundamental mathematical tools for quantitatively assessing risk. The application of these tools to problems encountered in actuarial analysis is emphasized. Topics include derivatives and integrals of multivariate functions, simple differential equations, general probability, Bayes’ Theorem, univariate and multivariate probability distributions.
outcome: The purposes of this course are (1) to introduce tools in probability theory for quantitatively assessing risk, and (2) to build a solid background in mathematics for uses in later courses. After following the course, students are expected to be• familiar with the basic mathematical tools that are useful in actuarial science• able to use probability to analyze risk• able to handle calculations involving univariate and multivariate probability distributions

title: Financial Mathematics for Actuaries
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course discusses the mathematical and technical aspects of the theory of interest in both discrete and continuous time. Topics include: measurement of interest and discount rates, accumulated value and present value, annuities, sinking funds, amortization of debt, determination of yield rates on securities and bond evaluations.
outcome: On completion of this course, students should be able to understand the time value of money and to calculate interest rates and discount factors. title: Statistics for Risk Modelling
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: The course is an introduction to mathematical statistics and basic risk modelling. Its goal is to help students understand the theoretical foundations of modern insurance analytics and risk management. The course covers the fundamental statistical concepts of inference, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing using the tools of probability theory.
outcome: After completing the course, students would acquire a knowledge in estimation and inference useful for actuarial work and predictive modeling.
syllabus: (1) Obtain parameter estimates of parametric distribution, and evaluate the properties of the estimates and compare different methods using the following notions: unbiasedness, efficiency, minimum variance, consistency, mean-square error.(2) Construct confidence intervals for parameters in simple set up related to mean and variance of normal distributions, and proportions of a population using CLT.(3) Understand the concept of statistical inference and compute the following for simple tests: level of significance (alpha), beta, power, p-value, critical region.(4) Construct critical regions of tests of hypothesis using Neyman-Pearson lemma and likelihood ratio tests (with the help of Wilk’s theorem). Derive classical tests for normal populations, proportions, and the chi-square goodness-of-fit test.(5) Understand the concept of Bayesian estimation, credibility interval, and Bayesian test.
required_readings: Hogg, Tanis, and Zimmerman (2015). Probability and Statistical Inference, 9th,. Pearson. (Chapters 5 to 9)

title: Actuarial Mathematics for Long-Term Insurance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the single decrement model in life contingencies. They would be able to formulate insurance and annuity benefits as random variables and perform calculations based on appropriate mortality assumptions. They would also be able to calculate premium and reserve under for simple products.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the single decrement model in life contingencies. They would be able to formulate insurance and annuity benefits as random variables and perform calculations based on appropriate mortality assumptions. They would also be able to calculate premium and reserve under for simple products.

Survival Distributions and Life Tables- Time-until-death and age-at-death random variables in both discrete and continuous forms; survival distributions; force of mortality; life table functions; random and deterministic survivorship group; introduction of recursion formulae; assumptions for fractional age; analytical laws of mortality; select and ultimate table2. title: Actuarial Mathematics for Short-Term Insurance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: The course aims to introduce students to severity models and frequency models and how they are used in short-term insurance coverages.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: (a) Pricing and Reserving for Short-Term Insurance Coverages; and (b) the characteristics of and uses for commonly used severity, frequency, and aggregate models.

title: Derivatives for Actuaries
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge in derivatives and their applications in pricing and reserving insurance products. Topics include financial forwards, futures, swaps, options; basic insurance strategies; parity relation; binominal option pricing models; the fundamental theorem of asset pricing; foundation of the Black-Scholes model; Brownian motion and stochastic calculus; derivation of Black-Scholes-Merton partial differential equation and Black-Scholes formula; volatility surface.

title: Data Science for Insurance Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: The course provides an overview of data science and insurance analytics, covering a broad selection of key challenges in and methodologies for working with big data. Topics include data collection, integration, management, modeling, analysis, visualization, prediction and informed decision making, as well as data security and data privacy. Students will acquire a working knowledge of insurance analytics through hands-on projects and case studies using R and Python (programme languages) with real financial and insurance datasets.
outcome: After completing the course, students would be able to use statistical packages to fit, interpret and select various statistical models, and use these models for forecasting and prediction.

title: Insurance and Risk Management
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management. The course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life; property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy.
outcome: It is anticipated that after this course students know where to find resources to effectively manage risks (uncertain variability in future outcomes over a specified time period in a given situation) faced personally, in professional careers and as managers in business, government, and other organizations. The intent of the course is to encourage the development of analytical and decision-making skills within the context of risk management (the decision-making process by which adverse consequences of risk are minimized). Students will be learning how to identify and evaluate property, liability and human resource risks, and how to effectively apply the best combination of risk control and risk financing tools including insurance. Concepts of risk management precede the review of insurance, which is a major risk treatment method.  Students are expected to be familiar with basic principles and practices of various insurance products.

title: Life Insurance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course covers laws and regulations of the life insurance, needs analysis, the life insurance contract, policy provisions and ownership rights, settlement options, pricing of life products, the underwriting function, medical insurance and long disability income policies.
outcome: On completion of this part of the course, students should be able to explain the major issues in the operation of life insurance, understand the marketing and underwriting functions of life insurance, as well as the factors affecting the competition in life insurance industry. For health insurance, students should be able to explain the major health care issues in America and Hong Kong, understand the basic characteristics of individual major medical insurance, long-term care insurance, as well as disability-income plans. Students should be able to develop guidelines when purchasing individual health insurance. With knowledge in this course, students should be able to contribute to the debate on health care policy and retirement financing reform in Hong Kong.

title: Commercial Property and Liability Insurance
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course examines risk management and operations of buyers and sellers of insurance. Basic principles and methods for assessing risks facing a non-insurance company and for selecting an optimal risk management programme are discussed in a broad insurance, finance, and statistical context. Because insurance is an important component of a risk management programme, the functional areas of providers of insurance (particularly property and casualty insurers) and the regulatory and market environment in which they operate are also discussed.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to perform: (a) comprehensive analysis of economic services, benefits, rates and rating theory, loss adjustment problems, legal theory factors, risk management concepts, loss prevention and transfer techniques and government regulation of public liability insurance,  (b) comprehensive analysis of loss control and transfer techniques (including insurance), risk management concepts, loss adjustment and underwriting problems, and profitability/regulatory issues concerning the insurance industry.

title: Loss and Survival Models
requirements: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
description: This course covers advanced concepts in short-term actuarial mathematics. Topics include credibility theory; limited fluctuation; Bayesian; Buhlmann; Buhlmann-Straub; empirical Bayes parameter estimation; statistical inference for loss models; maximum likelihood estimation; effect of policy modifications; model selection.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the statistical estimation and model selection principle of actuarial models used in general insurance. They would understand the framework of both classical and modern credibility theory as an approximation of Bayesian theory in insurance ratemaking. Students are expected to use spreadsheet programme and/or statistical packages to perform estimation of the models being studied.

title: Foundations of Financial Economics
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: This course intends to build a solid foundation of modern finance. It covers individual investment decisions under uncertainty, mean-variance portfolio theory, theory of capital market equilibrium, dynamic asset pricing. The principle of no arbitrage and its application will be emphasized throughout the course.

title: Real Estate Finance
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: The course is evenly divided between the study of real estate debt instruments and real estate equity instruments. The first section of the course focuses on real estate debt instruments. Topics in this section include mortgage mathematics, secondary mortgage market, mortgage securitization, RMBS and CMBS. The second section of the course discusses real estate equity securities. Topics include REITs and other forms of equity real estate investment including Commingled Real Estate Funds (CREFs) and Real Estate Limited Partnerships (RELPs).

title: Security Analysis
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: The objective of this course is to teach basic equity valuation methods and other security analysis techniques. The approach combines both accounting and finance into a practical framework for valuing firms, debt and equity. The emphasis of the course is on the practical application of finance and accounting to valuation.

title: Investment Strategies and Practices
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: The objective of this course is to teach investment strategies that are based on past price history. Trading strategies such as contrarian strategy and momentum strategy are discussed extensively. The course also covers the many investor behavioral biases as well as major trading principles in technical analysis.

title: Urban and Real Estate Economics
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: This course examines urban and real estate economics, illustrating how economic principles affect the demand for real estate, the operation of real estate markets, and the relationship between land use, land value and location. The overall objective of the course is to introduce the most important issues and topics in the study of cities and real estate markets, and to show how microeconomic principles can be used to critically analyze these problems.

title: Real Estate Investment Analysis
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: The course examines the analysis of real estate investments and property developments from the equity owner's/developer's point of view. Economic and financial concepts are applied to real estate analysis with the objective of building a solid foundation in the fundamentals of real estate valuation and deal structuring. The course will combine lectures with student discussions, case analysis, and presentations by real estate professionals in its review of the various disciplines involved in real estate investment analysis as well as a review of various types of income producing properties and development opportunities.

title: Derivatives Markets and Financial Engineering
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: This course examines the valuation and market structure of derivative securities. Topics include the role of derivative securities, the determination of forward and futures prices, hedging strategies using futures, trading strategies with futures, properties of options, the pricing of stock options, options on indices, currencies and futures contracts, risk analysis, applications of option pricing models, biases in the Black-Scholes model, interest rate options, exotic options, risk management with options, and trading strategies with options. The course demonstrates the ways in which financial innovations profoundly affect the alternatives available to corporations, investment managers, and financial intermediaries. While some technical aspects of financial engineering are going to be covered, many cases are chosen to bridge the gaps between theories and practices. Students are encouraged to use Excel, VBA or other computational tools to build and analyze models.

title: Internet Finance
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: The course provides the tools necessary to analyze the opportunities and potential competitive threats in commercial web-based organizations. To quantify and apply the analysis, a particular focus is on valuing Internet companies based on a careful examination of their business model and environment. The course also covers the basic theory of financial intermediation as it applies to online financial service firms. It discusses the impact of a migration to online financial services and the competitive changes created.

title: Fixed Income
requirements: For students in MBA Finance
description: This course aims to introduce valuation methods of fixed-income securities and investment techniques in managing fixed income portfolios. Topics include the term structures of interest rates and forward rates; bond pricing, risk and hedging in bond portfolio management; duration, convexity and portfolio immunization; corporate bonds, emerging-market bonds and default risks.
